OnNovember 1st. a further letter had been sent to both bodies, proposing a joint Conference withrepresentatives of the Mining Association and ofthe Miners' Federation to discuss the proposals.The Mining Association had declined to attend a^oint meeting. The Miners' Federation had aoceptedand had in fact attended on the previous day atthe time (2-30 p,m. ) specified in the letter ofNovember 1st. Their general attitude towards theGovernments proposals had been not unfavourable.The Mining Association, though they had not attended the Joint Conference, had also met the Cabinet coal committee on the previous evening. In spite ofall efforts by the Cabinet Coal Committee to induce them to attend a Joint Conference, they had declined, alleging that they had no authority toenter Into any Joint Conference. It was known thattheir real reason was that they were apprehensive of being drawn into discussions in regard to wages,whioh they were only prepared to discuss in the districts. The Owners' representatives were alsoopposed to the Government's proposals for areduction of hours, which they regarded as disastrous-trous to the mining industry.
